author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Catch a Bat
description: An air puffer can help stop biting. Use thick leather gloves anyway.
content: “Treat bats the way you would unvaccinated children,” says Winifred Frick, chief scientist at Bat Conservation International. Before Covid, biologists often blew on bats’ faces to get them to stop biting and on their underbellies to confirm their reproductive status. Don’t do that; you could inadvertently give a bat coronavirus. New bat-handling protocols suggest using an air-puffing tool like one of those baby-booger nasal aspirators to puff air on a bat instead. Also, wear a mask, get vaccinated and test negative for coronavirus before going out in the field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The top 1 percent are evading $163 billion a year in taxes, the Treasury finds.
description: A new report makes the case that narrowing the tax gap is part of the Biden administration’s ambition to create a more equitable economy.
content: WASHINGTON — The wealthiest 1 percent of Americans are the nation’s most egregious tax evaders, failing to pay as much as $163 billion in owed taxes per year, according to a Treasury Department report released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: Rebuilding Ground Zero Was a Mess. Lower Manhattan Bloomed Anyway.
description: A fraught reconstruction was a missed opportunity, but it helped foster a new urbanism and a broader vision of what a neighborhood can be.
content: The architects Michael Manfredi and Marion Weiss took to walking across the Brooklyn Bridge. Others started bicycling. For a while, a small flotilla, Dunkirk-like, ferried neighbors across the East River, colonizing the waterways as a sixth borough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bee Shapiro
title: The New Image Makers
description: In the world of haute hair, the hairstylists Jenna Perry and Jessica Gillin minister to some of the coolest girls in town.
content: Curtain bangs (a long 1970s-style swooping style) and wolf hair (a shaggy mullet). Glinting coppery red hues and ear-grazing chops inspired by the ’90s Delia’s catalog. If you’ve spotted these hair looks, chances are they were influenced by one East Village hot spot: the two-year-old Jenna Perry Hair salon, founded by the flame-haired Jenna Perry and featuring the precise head hairstylist Jessica Gillin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Trump Wants Your Money. Again.
description: The former president pines for his team to mention your name.
content: Donald Trump just can’t stop writing me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: On His Biggest Stage Yet, Derek Jeter Delivered One More Time
description: “I forgot how good that feels,” the former Yankees captain said as the crowd greeted him in Cooperstown with a warm, familiar salute.
content: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — The echoes last forever, but the real thing — that dizzying sound of mass admiration — rarely returns. Players are not rock stars; they cannot give performances decades past their prime, cannot summon, again and again, the same roars they earned long ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: California Recall Vote Could Weaken the State’s Aggressive Climate Policies
description: Many Republicans vying to replace Newsom as governor want to roll back the state’s ambitious plans to cut planet-warming emissions, a change with nationwide implications.
content: Follow our latest updates on the California Recall Election and Governor Newsom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: New York Fashion Week: Day 1
description: A sneaker meets a bed skirt in Brooklyn.
content: Fashion Week is back in full force, and there’s a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and you’ll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. Every day we’ll spotlight one thing we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Léontine Gallois
title: Armed Thieves Steal Jewels From Bulgari Store in Paris
description: A suspect is in custody after seven robbers made off with jewelry with an estimated value of millions from the luxury jewelry store in central Paris.
content: The three men, dressed in suits, could have passed for customers at the Bulgari store in central Paris. Armed with guns, however, their intentions were more nefarious. They stole a large haul of jewels from the Italian jewelry company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: Muslim Americans’ ‘Seismic Change’
description: The legacy of the 2001 attacks for Muslim Americans remains fraught, a story of struggle and of determination.
content: When Sylvia Chan-Malik reflects on the aftermath of Sept. 11, she has two starkly different personal memories from the trauma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Exercise for 3 Minutes, Every Half-Hour, to Counter the Ill Effects of Sitting
description: Climbing stairs, doing jumping jacks or even taking as few as 15 steps during mini-breaks improved blood sugar control among office workers.
content: Sitting for hours at a desk can play havoc with our metabolic health, contributing over time to high blood sugar and high cholesterol, even in people who otherwise seem mostly healthy. But a practical though small new study shows that standing up and moving every 30 minutes for about three minutes may lessen the health impacts of over-sitting. The study found that climbing several flights of stairs, bopping through some jumping jacks or squats or even taking as few as 15 steps during these mini-breaks improved aspects of blood sugar control among office workers, without noticeably interrupting their work flow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Hong Kong Police Arrest Organizers of Tiananmen Square Vigil
description: The group, which holds annual events to remember those killed during the 1989 crackdown, had refused to hand over funding details.
content: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong group that organizes vigils for the anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown said several of its leaders were arrested on Wednesday after it refused to provide information for a police investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Snyder and Stefan Ruiz
title: In Brazil, a House That Frames Its Landscape Like a Camera
description: By eliminating walls and color, the architect Marcio Kogan takes the form of a Trancoso fishing cottage to its most natural — yet elevated — ideal.
content: MARCIO KOGAN HAD been practicing architecture for a little over a decade when he decided to shut down his São Paulo, Brazil, firm for half a year to make his first full-length film. It was 1987, and he’d already completed 13 shorts, but creating a feature required choosing between what he then considered his two parallel callings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Aid Workers Staying in Taliban-Ruled Afghanistan Tread a Tricky Path
description: Afghanistan desperately needs aid. Nonprofits desperately want to provide it. But the aid groups are being tested as never before by the uncertainty that has followed the Taliban takeover.
content: Even as American and NATO forces and almost the entire Western diplomatic corps packed up and fled the Afghan capital last month as the Taliban seized control, a handful of international aid directors made a decision: They were staying put.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: A large earthquake near Acapulco shakes Mexico’s capital.
description: MEXICO CITY — A 7.1 magnitude earthquake struck near the port city of Acapulco Tuesday night, Mexico’s seismological agency said, shaking the capital, Mexico City, more than 230 miles away. At least one person was killed as a result, the authorities said.
content: MEXICO CITY — A 7.1 magnitude earthquake struck near the port city of Acapulco Tuesday night, Mexico’s seismological agency said, shaking the capital, Mexico City, more than 230 miles away. At least one person was killed as a result, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: Photographs of a Housing Crisis Worsened by Fire
description: The photographer Rachel Bujalski traveled to the Oregon towns burned by the Almeda fire last year even before she had an assignment.
content: For the past decade, Rachel Bujalski, a photographer based in San Francisco, has been documenting the inability of many people to find affordable housing in the United States. As part of this work, she has examined the devastating impact of wildfires that have left thousands of people homeless. She recently traveled to Ashland, Ore., in a region where the Almeda fire destroyed thousands of homes last September, and recorded the experiences of residents who are still displaced a year later for an article that was published Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: 3 Vermont State Troopers Investigated Over Fake Vaccination Cards
description: The officers have resigned, and federal authorities are investigating, the state police said this week.
content: Three Vermont state troopers accused of being involved in a fake Covid-19 vaccination card scheme have resigned amid a federal investigation, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: In California, a heat advisory and a wildfire season that is ‘far from over.’
description: Temperatures are expected to exceed 100 degrees in many parts of the state this week. And a top fire official warned that wildfires would continue to threaten communities for the rest of the year.
content: California’s wildfire season is “far from over” and the remainder of the year could be rough, a high-ranking fire official warned on Tuesday as thousands of firefighters across the state continued to battle at least a dozen large blazes threatening homes and communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: How Educational Differences Are Widening America’s Political Rift
description: College graduates are now a firmly Democratic bloc, and they are shaping the party’s future. Those without degrees, by contrast, have flocked to Republicans.
content: The front lines of America’s cultural clashes have shifted in recent years. A vigorous wave of progressive activism has helped push the country’s culture to the left, inspiring a conservative backlash against everything from “critical race theory” to the supposed cancellation of Dr. Seuss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Carlos Alcaraz’s Stirring U.S. Open Run Ends in the Quarterfinals
description: Alcaraz, an 18-year-old Spaniard, beat two seeded players in New York but retired with an injury midway through the second set on Tuesday night.
content: Carlos Alcaraz’s stunning run at the U.S. Open came to a sudden and surprising end on Tuesday night when the 18-year-old from Spain retired from his quarterfinal match against Felix Auger-Aliassime of Canada midway through the second set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How I Spent My Pandemic Year in a Camper Van’
description: In this lesson, students learn about the adventures of a New York Times travel reporter. Then, they plan their own road trip.
content: Note to our audience:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Covax, a global program to distribute Covid vaccines, cuts its 2021 forecast for available doses by a quarter.
description: The World Health Organization asked wealthy countries to hold off on administering booster shots for healthy patients until at least the end of the year.
content: The United Nations-backed program to vaccinate the world against the coronavirus slashed its forecast for doses available in 2021 by roughly a quarter on Wednesday, another setback for an effort that has been hampered by production problems, export bans and vaccine hoarding by wealthy nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: The Trial of Theranos’s Elizabeth Holmes Opens
description: A jury will decide whether Ms. Holmes, who founded Theranos and hawked a mission of revolutionizing health care, lied to investors about her company’s technology.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — The defendant, wearing a gray suit, sat quietly at a table surrounded by lawyers, her expression hidden behind a blue medical mask. Occasionally, she looked around. Her boyfriend and family members sat, also masked, in the packed gallery of Courtroom 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Cliff and Brian Fernandes
title: Covid Zero Is No Longer Working for Australia
description: The country’s tight restrictions are no longer working against Delta. It’s time for a strategy change.
content: Australia was, until recently, heralded for its effective suppression of Covid-19; through strict border closures, prolonged lockdowns and its fortune as a remote island continent, the country was able to avoid a large-scale outbreak. The Delta variant has, however, turned that success upside down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Growing Wildflowers Isn’t Difficult. And It’s Urgent.
description: In a shifting climate, with environmental diversity at risk, it’s never been more important to propagate native plants. Here’s how.
content: The native perennial species of our meadows — milkweeds, asters, Joe Pye weed and others — will make one more offering in fall, as if they haven’t given enough already. They will offer up their seed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Signs of old Taliban tactics.
content: The Taliban announced a caretaker government on Tuesday, taking a major step in re-establishing their Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan and empowering many of the movement’s loyalists from their regime in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Will Return to Its Courtroom Next Month
description: The public will not be allowed in, but the court will continue to provide live audio of arguments.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court will resume hearing arguments in person when its new term starts in October, after a break of more than a year in response to the coronavirus pandemic, the court announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Extraordinary Actresses on Their Ordinary Roles in ‘Morning Sun’
description: Edie Falco, Blair Brown and Marin Ireland portray three generations of women sharing the same Greenwich Village walk-up in Simon Stephens’s new play.
content: Simon Stephens’s “Morning Sun,” Edie Falco insisted, is not a big play. It isn’t epic or tragic or especially momentous. Its characters don’t change the world. They barely cast a shadow. Which Falco likes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Senior Russian Minister Dies During Drill
description: The government said Yevgeny Zinichev, a longtime Putin aide responsible for emergency situations, dived off a cliff to save a film director who fell into the water.
content: MOSCOW — A senior government official died on Wednesday when he dove off a cliff trying to save a prominent film director who had fallen into the water during a drill in Russia’s Far North, officials confirmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthieu Aikins, Salman Masood and Marc Santora
title: As Taliban Crush Dissent, New Leaders Face Cascading Challenges
description: The Taliban continued to brutally crack down on demonstrations against their rule. The new government faces an unfolding humanitarian crisis and flaring tensions on the Afghan-Pakistan border.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Only one day after the Taliban named an acting cabinet to lead the nation they spent two decades trying to conquer, the dizzying challenges that accompanied victory were coming into sharp relief Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed’s Williams hints that bond-buying taper could start even if job gains slow.
description: The president of the powerful New York Fed said that it was the level of the job market, not the pace of progress, that mattered.
content: John C. Williams, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and a powerful monetary policy official, hinted on Wednesday that it might be possible for the central bank to begin removing support for the economy before the end of the year even if the job market grows at a lackluster pace in coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez
title: Abortion Is No Longer a Crime in Mexico. But Most Women Still Can’t Get One.
description: The Supreme Court’s decision set a legal precedent for the nation. But applying it to all of Mexico’s states will be a long path, and women are still facing prosecution.
content: MEXICO CITY — When the Supreme Court in Mexico issued a historic decision on Tuesday declaring that having an abortion was not a crime, activists across the country celebrated. On Wednesday, they got back to work, taking on the long and arduous process of ensuring that the legal shift applies across Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael R. Bloomberg
title: Michael Bloomberg: How New York City Can Bounce Back, Again
description: How the next mayor could build a better, safer city after the pandemic.
content: The future of New York City is being called into question. Neighborhoods have lost residents to the suburbs. Businesses have closed. People are on edge about public safety. And families are mourning the loss of loved ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed and Raphael Minder
title: High Natural Gas Prices Strain Europeans, Weighing on Recovery
description: Crimped supplies and increased demand have pushed energy prices to their highest in years, raising concerns about the winter.
content: LONDON — As the world struggles to recover from the pandemic, soaring natural gas prices threaten to become a drag on the economies of Europe and elsewhere. Wholesale prices for the fuel are at their highest in years — nearly five times where they were at this time in 2019, before people started falling ill with the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A Pandemic, Then a Hurricane, Brings New Orleans Musicians ‘to Their Knees’
description: A few historic jazz sites were damaged in the storm. But the bigger blows struck artists and clubs struggling to get back to business after Covid-19 shutdowns.
content: When Hurricane Ida swept through New Orleans late last month, it took a piece of history with it. The Karnofsky Tailor Shop and Residence, a decrepit red brick building that had served as a kind of second home for Louis Armstrong during his boyhood in the early 1900s, was reduced to rubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: California’s Farms Face a Reckoning
description: Eighty percent of the water used by people in California goes to just 0.8 percent of the state’s gross domestic product.
content: The advantage of growing crops in an arid climate is that you rarely have to worry about too much rain. You can precisely control the moisture your crops get through irrigation. At the same time, the sunny days promote rapid plant growth. You can produce far more bounteous harvests in, say, California’s Imperial Valley, which gets about three inches of rain a year, than somewhere back east that’s cloudy and sometimes too rainy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yaniv Iczkovits
title: A Writer Reckons With the Fact That ‘People Love Dead Jews’
description: Dara Horn’s new essay collection looks at the ways the Jewish past has been contorted to elide the actual realities of anti-Semitism.
content: PEOPLE LOVE DEAD JEWSReports From a Haunted PresentBy Dara Horn
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: House Hunting in Turks and Caicos: Open-Air, Oceanfront Solitude
description: The pandemic has spurred a new wave of prosperous buyers to invest in the British Overseas Territory with the tax-friendly disposition.
content: This three-bedroom villa is set back from a 40-foot cliff overlooking the Atlantic Ocean on the island of South Caicos, one of nine inhabited islands and cays in the Turks and Caicos archipelago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Vast Expansion in Aid Kept Food Insecurity From Growing Last Year
description: Despite the economic downturn, government figures for 2020 show no overall rise in hunger of the sort typical in past recessions. But some groups still suffered.
content: As 20 million jobs vanished at the start of the coronavirus pandemic and traffic jams formed outside food banks, many experts warned that the twin crises of unemployment and disease would produce soaring rates of hunger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: Virginia Removes Robert E. Lee Statue From State Capital
description: The Confederate memorial was erected in 1890, the first of six monuments that became symbols of white power along the main boulevard in Richmond.
content: RICHMOND, Va. — One of the nation’s largest Confederate monuments — a soaring statue of Robert E. Lee, the South’s Civil War general — was hoisted off its pedestal in downtown Richmond, Va., on Wednesday, bringing to an end the era of Confederate statues in the city that is best known for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: He Had Chest Pain and Dangerously Low Blood Pressure. What Was Wrong?
description: Could a wayward breath mint have caused his symptoms?
content: The young woman was awakened by the screams of her 39-year-old husband. “Please make it stop!” he shouted, leaping from the bed. “It hurts!” He paced back and forth across the room, arms crossed over his chest as if to protect himself. Two days earlier, he had inhaled a breath mint when his wife startled him. He felt it move slowly down his throat as he swallowed repeatedly. His chest had hurt ever since. But not like this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: In ‘Return the Moon,’ Theater Between Phases
description: While insubstantial, this immersive online performance gathers people virtually until they can get together more safely in person.
content: A quirk of astronomy: The phases of the moon appear the same no matter where you stand on Earth. If it’s gibbous in Greenland, it’s gibbous in Argentina; a crescent is a crescent from New Zealand to Uzbekistan. As I write this, a new moon approaches, and all over the world stars shine brighter now. Over the past year and a half, there have been fewer opportunities to watch the same thing at the same time in person, so what a miracle that if any of us were to stand outside, we might, for a moment, see the same bright thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Phil Schaap, Grammy-Winning Jazz D.J. and Historian, Dies at 70
description: His radio programs, most notably on Columbia University’s WKCR, were full of minutiae he had accumulated during a lifetime immersed in the genre.
content: Phil Schaap, who explored the intricacy and history of jazz in radio programs that he hosted, Grammy-winning liner notes that he wrote, music series that he programmed and classes that he taught, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: For Raducanu and Fernandez, the Magical Run Goes On and On
description: The teenagers from Britain and Canada have advanced to the semifinals at the U.S. Open. (The run certainly surprised Emma Raducanu, who had a flight home booked after the qualifying tournament.)
content: There they go again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Lindsey Buckingham Has Survived It All
description: After a heart attack and (another) feud with Stevie Nicks, the former Fleetwood Mac guitarist returns with a new solo album.
content: LOS ANGELES — One day in early February 2019, Lindsey Buckingham woke up to a wallop of a surprise: He had just had a heart attack, followed by an emergency triple bypass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell Us What You Love About the Outdoors for Our Black History Series
description: For our series exploring pivotal moments and transformative figures in Black history, we want to hear stories about when you found your passion for nature.
content: How do you find purpose, joy and peace in the great outdoors?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Macy’s plans a vaccinated Thanksgiving Day parade that will resume many traditions.
description: The holiday show, in its 95th year, will travel a longer route than it did last year and have more participants, including visiting marching bands.
content: Participants in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade must be masked and vaccinated, with a few exceptions, the company said on Wednesday, as the annual tradition plans a return to a version of its old self this November after a muted performance last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Ephrat Livni
title: Coinbase says the S.E.C. has threatened to sue it over a plan to pay interest.
description: Coinbase’s Lend offering — an interest-generating service that somewhat resembles accounts traditionally offered by banks — could violate securities laws, the Securities and Exchange Commission said.
content: Coinbase, the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the United States, said on Wednesday that federal securities regulators were threatening to sue it over a proposed financial product that would let customers earn interest on digital asset deposits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: Sometimes I Hate My Husband’s Peloton
description: Yes, exercise is hugely beneficial. But can too much of a good thing cause tension in your relationship?
content: At the peak of the pandemic, my husband was embroiled in a full-blown love affair. It made him frequently unavailable, led to several surprising credit card statements and impinged upon family time. To quote Princess Diana, I started to feel that there were three of us in this marriage — and one of us was an exercise bike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Navy Helicopter Vibrated Before Falling Into the Sea, Report Says
description: The MH-60S Seahawk’s main rotor struck the deck of the U.S.S. Abraham Lincoln before the helicopter fell overboard near San Diego and killed five sailors, according to a Navy safety report.
content: A U.S. Navy helicopter that crashed off the coast near San Diego last week, killing five sailors, landed on an aircraft carrier and experienced vibrations before its main rotor struck the flight deck and the aircraft fell into the ocean, the Navy said in a safety report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: The New ‘Shadow’ Banks
description: The crypto revolution is bringing financial services to the unbanked, but not without risks.
content: Cryptocurrency is transforming the way people save and borrow money, and a slew of new businesses are popping up to provide services that resemble bank offerings. But this fast-growing crypto-finance sector has officials in Washington worried, The Times’s Eric Lipton and DealBook’s Ephrat Livni report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: What Does It Mean to ‘Never Forget’?
description: Twenty years after Sept. 11, a look at what we hold on to and what we choose to let go.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: California Senate Passes Bill Reining In Amazon Labor Model
description: The bill would curb production quotas at Amazon and other companies that critics say are excessive and force workers to forgo bathroom breaks.
content: In the latest sign of the growing scrutiny of Amazon’s labor practices, the California State Senate on Wednesday approved a bill that would place limits on production quotas for warehouse workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Keep Keeping a Logbook
description: Notes on the passage of time.
content: Welcome. I pruned the trailing jade plant yesterday, made a noodle kugel for Rosh Hashana and rode my bike into Manhattan for dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marion Renault
title: Komodo Dragons Are Now Endangered and ‘Moving Toward Extinction’
description: A top conservation organization updated the status of the fierce giant lizards on its Red List of threatened species.
content: The Komodo dragon has earned its status as a reptilian icon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Whether Dancing or Still, the Body in ‘Ema’ Tells the Story
description: In Pablo Larraín’s unsettling film, Mariana Di Girolamo stars as a dancer who finds freedom through reggaeton dance.
content: Ema is the oddest of things: a dancer with a passion for setting things on fire. In “Ema,” Pablo Larraín’s film, the title character has a particular look, too: bleached hair slicked back so severely that it appears to be shellacked to her head. That hairstyle, hard and impenetrable, is like a coat of armor, which makes sense. Ema is made of ice. Until she dances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Ng
title: Could Robots From Boston Dynamics Beat Me in a Fight?
description: A parkour showcase of the agile humanoids is both wondrous and unsettling.
content: In a vast warehouse-style room, two humanoid robots are taking on an obstacle course. Their barrel-shaped torsos, stuffed with processors and batteries, make it look as if they’ve been going to the gym a lot but have neglected leg day. They run and jump, traipsing on and off blocks and angled steps not unlike those in the qualifying round of the obstacle-​course show “American Ninja Warrior.” One runs along a beam and then, later, vaults over it. For the finale, they position themselves on opposite corners of a table and do two synchronized back flips. Feet firmly on the ground, they celebrate: One brushes off its shoulders, the other raises its arms in triumph. Neither, obviously, has broken a sweat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: First Host of ‘Blue’s Clues’ Returns, Striking a Chord With Grown-Ups
description: Steve Burns, who had a complicated relationship with the popular children’s show he hosted for six years, addressed his viewers almost two decades after his “kind of abrupt” departure.
content: One day in 2002, Steve Burns packed up a bulging backpack and suitcase, said farewell to a speckled blue dog and a room of cartoon furniture, and disappeared into a two-dimensional school bus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Solar Power, Afghanistan, Derek Jeter: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Trial Begins Over November 2015 Paris Terrorist Attacks
description: The assaults carried out by Islamic State extremists that killed 130 people deeply rattled France and sent shock waves across Europe. The proceedings are scheduled to last at least nine months.
content: PARIS — The trial of 20 men accused of involvement in the November 2015 attacks in Paris began on Wednesday, nearly six years after the coordinated and devastating assault that left over 100 dead and shook France to its core.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Your Batteries Are Due for Disruption
description: This week, a more efficient type of battery arrives in a wristband fitness tracker. It could soon reach smart glasses, cars and even aircraft.
content: ALAMEDA, Calif. — The new Whoop fitness tracker straps around the wrist, a lot like any other health monitor or smartwatch. But you can also buy a sports bra or leggings equipped with this tiny device, which can be a sliver of electronics stitched into the fabric of clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Who Made My Crossword?
description: This month’s constructor spotlight shines on Yacob Yonas.
content: I’m a huge fan of early 2000s R&B, so anything by Usher or Ne-Yo!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tropical Storm Mindy Hits the Florida Panhandle
description: The 13th named storm of the 2021 Atlantic hurricane season, Mindy made landfall on Wednesday night, just hours after it formed in the Gulf of Mexico.
content: The quick-moving Tropical Storm Mindy hit the Florida Panhandle where more than 13,000 customers had lost power on Thursday. More than half of those customers are in the City of Tallahassee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Jill Cowan

title: The Simple Perfection of Fried Eggs and White Rice
description: The great thing about egg rice is that it’s hardly cooking. If you can fry an egg, then you can make egg rice.
content: Every two weeks, Christina Dang buys a carton of 18 eggs from the Costco near her home in San Diego. Most of these eggs go into a snack she makes for herself when she comes home from work: egg rice. She fries a single egg sunny-side up and places it on a small plate of leftover jasmine rice. Then, over the yolk, she pours a little Maggi sauce, a dark, savory potion of wheat protein. For Dang, who is a pharmacist, there’s a ritual to eating this simple but potent dish, one she has upheld since she was young. She breaks the yolk and mixes the Maggi into it, creating a makeshift gravy that drapes the rice in eggy gold. She pierces her fork straight down into the food, so she has an even distribution of Maggi-tinged yolk, crisp-edged egg white and steamed white rice, fluffy as a fresh-raked pile of leaves, on her tines. “I eat this at least once a day,” she told me.
